images.caption: Figure 2:Method overview. The input image is passed through an encoder that produces multiple tokens to represent it. These tokens are projected to form the keys and values of the nested attention layers. The result of each nested attention layer is a new set of per-query values,Vq‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëâùëûV_{q}^{*}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which then replace the cross-attention values of the tokens‚àósuperscriptùë†s^{*}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTrepresenting the subject. One nested attention layer is added to each of the cross-attention layers of the model.

Figure 3:The nested attention mechanism. We replace the value of the tokens‚àósuperscriptùë†s^{*}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTwith the result of an attention operation between the query and the nested keys and values produced by the encoder, resulting in a query-dependent value.

Figure 4:We visualize the valuesVq‚Å¢[s‚àó]subscriptùëâùëûdelimited-[]superscriptùë†V_{q}[s^{*}]italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]generated for a subject in two different layers, with a vanilla cross-attention, and with our nested approach. Vanilla layers use the same value to represent the subject throughout the entire image (column 3). Nested attention assigns a different subject-value per query (columns 4 and 5), encoding fine-grained semantic information.

Figure 5:Analyzing the query-dependent values (Vq‚Å¢[s‚àó]subscriptùëâùëûdelimited-[]superscriptùë†V_{q}[s^{*}]italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]) from a nested attention layer. For three queries of the generated image (purple, orange, blue points), we first show their attention maps in a nested attention layer (graph). There, each point corresponds to a token produced by the encoder. In each graph, 1-2 tokens dominate the attention. To analyze the information encoded in the most dominant token, we show the Q-Former attention map of its corresponding learned query. These show the semantic alignment between the probed query, and the source of values assigned to it.
Figure 6:Attention maps between Q-Former learned queries and input image features. Each column shows a distinct query‚Äôs attention map, illustrating how queries capture different facial features.
Figure 7:Qualitative results of our method trained on human faces (left) and pets (right). The sampled noise is fixed across each column.

Figure 8:By manipulating the attention given to the personalized token, we control the identity-editability tradeoff.ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œªdenotes the factor in which we increase the attention to the special token.

Figure 9:Comparing nested attention with decoupled cross attention.ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œªbalances between identity preservation and prompt alignment.
We use the followingŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œªvalues from left to right (top two rows). Decoupled CA: 0.5, 0.6, 1.0, nested attention: 1.0, 2.0, 4.0.
Our method achieves better identity preservation while being aligned with the text prompt.

Figure 10:Quantitative comparison of various personalization injection mechanisms. All models were trained from scratch under the same setting, with a resolution of512√ó512512512512\times 512512 √ó 512.

Figure 11:Left: qualitative comparison of human faces personalization methods. Our method successfully changes expressions and pose while preserving the identity. Right: quantitative comparison. Methods that use CLIP as their backbone encoder are marked with filled markers, while methods that build on face recognition models as their backbone encoder are marked with unfilled markers.
Figure 13:Using multiple images of the same concept increases the subject‚Äôs fidelity in the generated image.
Figure 14:Our method allows mixing two identities by encoding them separately, and pass the concatenated representations to the nested attention layer.
Figure 15:By simply changing at inference time the token to which we inject the personalized concept (e.g., ‚Äúperson‚Äù to ‚Äúwoman‚Äù) we can have various semantic variations.

Figure 16:Qualitative comparison of injection mechanism.ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œªbalances between identity preservation and prompt alignment.
We use the followingŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œªvalues from left to right. Decoupled CA: 0.5, 0.6, 1.0, globalVùëâVitalic_V, multiple tokens and nested attention: 1.0, 2.0, 4.0.

Figure 17:Ablating the regularization performed onVq‚Å¢[s‚àó]subscriptùëâùëûdelimited-[]superscriptùë†V_{q}[s^{*}]italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]. Without normalization, the image looks red and contains artifacts. SettingŒ±=2ùõº2\alpha=2italic_Œ± = 2provides a good balance between identity preservation and prior preservation.

Figure 18:Results of models trained with varying number of learned queries. Increasing the number of learned queries improves identity preservation. All models used in this figure underwent only the first phase of training.
Figure 19:Additional results on human faces. The initial noise is fixed across each column.
Figure 20:Additional results on pets. The initial noise is fixed across each column.
